PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A VIEW OF SURVIVAL ON THE PERSON

SURVIVING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another.

Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, or don't apply about leaving blank spaces. DON'T

turn sheets of paper if there is any difficulty in answering the questions. DON'T hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whatever born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets of paper for a separate questionnaire.

To Sask., May, 1951

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person submitting this questionnaire:

It has been difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because some of the experiences listed are not exactly the same experiences as an individual. For your convenience, we will not reply to your experiences unless they may prove helpful to others who may be interested in the pioneer life.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer First: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Enjoy?" is still being circulated. If you have not already sent one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared as willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? W.R. Fallis

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may have been a small child, shown in my teens, etc.)
   4½ years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My Father had heard of the opportunity of the west and decided to bring his family to seek his fortune.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

Father had a friend who had come west a few years earlier, and had a lumber yard in Montana. So Father came with him and bought machinery, etc., to work on and run from Edmonton through the district until he located a farm to his liking five miles east of Morin, near the main line of C.P.R.

Mr. Harry Wilson, Dec. 30, 1908, at Wilton, Saskatchewan.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? Yes

My brother, two sisters, and mother came west in 1894 because of better conditions.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west tell when they came and where they settled.

They settled in the main mining district.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

One thing I remember well was the prairie fires. One night after midnight the sky was lit up with smoke, burning for miles. There was no wind, so we gathered around building up for the smoke. The family was divided into two groups, one group with wet sacks and blankets and the other with dry sacks and blankets. We waited until the fire passed us by, then we turned our backs on the fire and walked away.
